title: Auditory Nerve Involvement: Large CPA Tumor and Neurofibromatosis
chief_complaint: I have been noticing hearing loss and ringing in my right ear for about 9 months. I also feel fullness in that ear sometimes, and I've noticed I can't hear well on the phone when I hold it to my right side.

problem_summary.onset: Hearing loss and tinnitus began approximately 9 months ago; vertigo began 4 years ago.
problem_summary.course: Intermittent vertigo for 4 years; hearing symptoms present for 9 months; pulsatile tinnitus for a 3-week period recently.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus (sometimes pulsatile), aural fullness, difficulty hearing on the telephone, intermittent vertigo with head turns, occasional bilateral earaches.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty using the telephone with the right ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking diagnosis for unilateral auditory symptoms and vertigo.

history.present_illness: The patient is a 29-year-old nurse. She reports right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus of 9 months' duration. She experienced pulsatile tinnitus for 3 weeks within that period and notes intermittent aural fullness. A few weeks prior to the visit, she noticed she could not hear well on the phone with the right ear.
history.medical_psych_history: 4-year history of intermittent vertigo, often brought on by turning her head quickly. No family history of neurofibromatosis reported initially.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear thresholds are normal. Right ear shows an unusual sensorineural configuration with a sharp dip to severe loss at 2000 Hz, rising to normal sensitivity at 6000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent recognition in the left ear. Very poor recognition in the right ear, disproportionate to the pure tone average (retrocochlear sign).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal for left ear stimulation (ipsi and contra). Absent for right ear stimulation (ipsi and contra) at 500-4000 Hz.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Readable Wave I at normal latency, but poorly defined/questionable Wave V at ~7.4 msec. Left ear: Normal Waves I-IV, Wave V slightly extended. Wave I amplitude is larger than IV-V complex bilaterally.

tests.name: MRI
tests.key_findings: Large mass in the right Cerebellopontine Angle (CPA) compressing the brainstem and extending into the cerebellum. A second mass was found in the superior parietal lobe.

overall_audiologic_summary: This 29-year-old patient presented with right-sided sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. Audiometric testing revealed a 'cookie-bite' like notch at 2000 Hz in the right ear with disproportionately poor speech recognition (14%). Acoustic reflexes were absent with right ear stimulation. ABR indicated retrocochlear pathology on the right (delayed/poor Wave V) and possible contralateral brainstem compression effects on the left (extended Wave V). MRI confirmed a large 4-5 cm right CPA mass and a second parietal lobe tumor, leading to a diagnosis of neurofibromatosis (likely NF2).
counseling_points: Explain the discrepancy between the pure tone thresholds (hearing some tones) and the inability to understand speech (14% score), indicating nerve involvement.
Discuss the MRI findings showing the mass in the auditory nerve area (CPA) and the secondary mass in the brain.
Refer immediately to neuro-otology/neurosurgery for management of the tumors.
Discuss the diagnosis of neurofibromatosis and the need for genetic counseling and monitoring of the other ear (as NF often affects both sides eventually).
Prepare the patient for the likelihood of total hearing loss in the right ear following surgical removal of the large tumor.
notes_for_actor: You are a young professional (nurse). You might be surprised that such a large tumor was found because your symptoms, while annoying, didn't feel 'severe' enough to explain a 5cm brain tumor.
You have been dizzy for 4 years when turning your head, but you may have dismissed it or learned to live with it.
The hearing loss on the phone is a recent and specific frustration.
You have no known family history of this condition, so the diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis is unexpected.
